<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskDelay_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskDelay_Impl(uint32 millisecond)
{
    struct timespec sleep_end;
    int             status;

    clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &sleep_end);
    sleep_end.tv_sec += millisecond / 1000;
    sleep_end.tv_nsec += 1000000 * (millisecond % 1000);

    if (sleep_end.tv_nsec >= 1000000000)
    {
        sleep_end.tv_nsec -= 1000000000;
        ++sleep_end.tv_sec;
    }

    do
    {
        status = clock_nanosleep(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, TIMER_ABSTIME, &sleep_end, NULL);
    } while (status == EINTR);

    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        return OS_SUCCESS;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskDelay_Impl:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 17.8 forbids modifying function parameters (the parameter object itself); pointer-referred objects may be modified but the pointer shall not be modified. In OS_TaskDelay_Impl the sole parameter is 'uint32 millisecond'. The code only reads 'millisecond' in expressions (millisecond / 1000, millisecond % 1000) and does not assign to it or apply ++/+=, so the parameter is not modified. The function calls clock_gettime(..., &sleep_end) and clock_nanosleep(..., &sleep_end, NULL) pass the address of the local variable 'sleep_end' so the called functions may modify that object — this is permitted by the rule. No pointer parameter variable is modified in this function. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for Rule 17.8.
